titleproper.value:
Guide to the Miriam Nyhan Oral History Collection
                    <num>AIA.036</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Rachel Searcy

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2015-04-29T14:14-0400</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: Miriam Nyhan is an Adjunct Assistant Professor of Irish Studies and Program Coordinator at New York University's Glucksman Ireland House. She received her BA and MPhil degrees from University College Cork (NUI) and her PhD from the European University Institute in Florence. Her research often focuses on oral history and Irish immigration patterns. This collection consists of 11 interviews conducted by Nyhan in 2006 as part of her PhD research. She interviewed Irish immigrants, many of whom emigrated in the 1950s and settled in New York, to perform comparative research of Irish migration patterns. The interviewees in this collection discuss their early lives, family, education, occupation , emigration experiences, social lives in their new homes, and any involvement in Irish American social, cultural, or fraternal organizations.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Miriam Nyhan Oral History Collection; AIA 036; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Due to a lack of documentation, it is unclear when the materials were donated to the archives or by whom. The accession number associated with this gift is 1997.037.

Miriam Nyhan is an Adjunct Assistant Professor of Irish Studies and Program Coordinator at New York University's Glucksman Ireland House. She received her BA and MPhil degrees from University College Cork (NUI) and her PhD from the European University Institute in Florence. Her research often focuses on oral history and Irish immigration patterns. Some of her publications include 
                <emph render="italic">"Are You Still Below?": The Ford Marina Plant, Cork, 1917-1984</emph>, "Narration and Memory: The Experiences of the Workforce of a Ford Plant" in 
                <emph render="italic">Irish Economic and Social History</emph> (2006), and "La Fuerza de Trabaja en Una Planta Ford" in 
                <emph render="italic">Historia and Antropologia y Fuentes Orales</emph> (2007). She teaches courses on modern Irish history and comparative migration history.

This collection consists of 11 interviews conducted by Miriam Nyhan in 2006 as part of her PhD research while studying at the European University Institute in Florence. Nyhan interviewed Irish immigrants, many of whom emigrated in the 1950s and settled in New York, to perform comparative research of Irish migration patterns. The interviewees in this collection discuss their early lives, family, education, occupation , emigration experiences, social lives in their new homes, and any involvement in Irish American social, cultural, or fraternal organizations.

subject.value: Irish Americans |z New York (State) |z New York.
